thread.title_full: Gilas two wins from glory, beats Lebanon | mb.com.ph | Philippine News

author: Waylon Galvez
title: Gilas two wins from glory, beats Lebanon
text:
by Waylon Galvez
October 2, 2015 (updated) Changsha, China — The road to the finals became just a little bit easier for the Philippines last night after bringing down dangerous Lebanon, 82-70, putting it in a semifinal encounter with Japan which Gilas Pilipinas beat earlier in the second round of the FIBA Asia Championship.
The score did not reflect the difficult match against Lebanon which fought with everything it had to deny the Philippines but just could not get the shots and the breaks against a stifling Gilas defense which also produced an offense which Lebanon could not stop.
With the win, the Philippines, making its third straight semifinal stint in the Asian Championship, moved to within two games of winning everything. The country hasn’t won this tournament since 1985.
Terrence Romeo scores off Lebanon’s Jay Youngblood during their quarterfinal match in the FIBA Asia Championship in Changsha, China last night. Gilas Pilipinas won, 82-70, to arrange a semifinal showdown with Japan. (FIBA Asia Photo)
Next for Gilas is Japan which many consider will be an easier opponent for the Philippines when they play today at 9:30 p.m. Japan eliminated Qatar in the other quarterfinal match.
Iran and China clash in the other semifinals after outclassing South Korea and India, respectively.
Two more wins and the Philippines will become king of Asian basketball again.
But the real prize, should Gilas go all the way, is a stint in the Rio Olympics next year, a tantalizing prospect for a team that came to the championship as underdogs. The FIBA Asia winner offers the lone Olympic slot for the region. The last time the Philippines played in the Olympics was in 1972 in Munich.
Jayson Castro once again delivered for Gilas with 25 points, punctuated by a booming three-pointer, his fifth and final of the game, that gave his team a 74-62 lead with 2:12 left in the game.
Naturalized Andray Blatche also had a huge game with 24 points, 17 rebounds, three assists and two blocks despite hurting his right shoulder following a hard foul by his Lebanon counterpart Jay Youngblood.
“We got the win, that’s the most important thing,” said Blatche, before responding to a statement made by Lebanon Coach Veselin Matic, who on Tuesday called the Gilas battle as “easy”.
“They had a lot to say before the game. We know it won’t come easy, but we took them out and shut them up.”
Gilas took a 61-52 lead on a three by Gabe Norwood early in the fourth quarter but saw Lebanon cut the margin to 61-57 on a Youngblood triple with 6:52 left to the delight of a Chinese crowd hoping for an upset.
But the Filipinos countered the mini-run of the Lebanese as Blatche connived with Terrence Romeo, Marc Pingris and Castro with crucial baskets to spark a celebration headed by Samahang Basketbol ng Pilipinas President Manny V. Pangilinan.
“I’m pretty sure (the Chinese fans) want to see (Lebanon) rather than us,” said Blatche, who shrugged off jeers by the Chinese crowd by making four straight free throws late. “I’m used to that (jeers), I played in bigger level.”
PHILIPPINES 82 – Castro 25, Blatche 24, Romeo 10, Pingris 8, Abueva 7, Norwood 5, De Ocampo 3, Ganuelas 0, Thoss 0, Hontiveros 0.
LEBANON 70 – Haidar 18, Bawji 17, Youngblood 12, AB Del nour 8, Arakji 8, Saoud 7, Akl 0.
Quarters: 20-16; 37-32; 57-49; 82-70.
